data.title: Transition from task 0.1.0 to 2.0.0 produces errors
data.body:
Refs: #34953

OS X

1. Follow the exect steps from Task testplan
2. Once you finish the 0.1.0 version, for version 2.0.0 continue in the same workspace, but just delete the `tasks.json` file
3. Continue with the 2.0.0 test and once you select the problem matcher $tsc notice an error in the message service
4. Running my task does not work and I am getting errors

Note that once I reload vscode everything works nicely.
I believe tasks framework should handle the case of tasks.json deletion and it should handle the transisiton to 2.0.0 more gracefully

![screen shot 2017-09-26 at 11 00 50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/30852053-cfb45c34-a2aa-11e7-898a-bfc8a4264377.png)

data.title: Menu bar visibility toggling when it should't

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm running on a Linux environment using Gnome. I have the `window.menuBarVisibility` setting set to `toggle` which is triggered with the `Alt` key. Unfortunately, when I switch desktops using the default keyboard shortcut of `Ctrl+Alt+[arrow]`, VSCode seems to think I've pressed `Alt` and it toggles the menu bar every time which is really annoying.

I tried changing the keyboard shortcut to `Alt+M` to toggle visibility but VSCode seems to still make it also toggle with `Alt` no matter what shortcut I set. The shortcut I configure just becomes an additional way to toggle it. I then tried setting the menu bar visibility to `hidden` hoping that would disable `Alt` so it would only toggle with my configured shortcut but once I press my configured toggle shortcut VSCode will go and change my setting from `hidden` back to `toggle` thus re-enabling the `Alt` shortcut to toggle.

There needs to be a way to either disable/change the `Alt` menu toggle shortcut or at the very least not trigger it when I switch desktops holding `Ctrl+Alt+[arrow]`.

data.title: Test: File system provider API
data.body:
Test for: #34218
Complexity: 4

- [ ] Linux - @joaomoreno 

We have added *proposed* API for file system provider. They allow you add a new root node to the explorer (currently implemented as adding a workspace folder), allow for file creation/discovery/saving etc. 

For testing, write a file system provider. To keep things simple, I suggest to implement a "localhost"-provider, that represents files on your computer and uses the node API. A sample of an FTP provider is here: https://github.com/jrieken/ftp-sample. You are obviously free to take a more complex sample, like `tar`-files or `ssh` but at the risk of spending much time understanding how the backends work

1. Note that you need to register your provider for a [scheme](https://github.com/jrieken/ftp-sample/blob/276615f7814e3a250473eeba65d345654153a164/src/extension.ts#L13) and that your provider needs to provide a [root](https://github.com/jrieken/ftp-sample/blob/276615f7814e3a250473eeba65d345654153a164/src/extension.ts#L26)
2. Note that your extension needs to use a new (and undocumented) activation event which is [`onFileSystemAccess:<your_scheme>`](https://github.com/jrieken/ftp-sample/blob/276615f7814e3a250473eeba65d345654153a164/package.json#L14)

This is feature ready and all done but the purpose is to that we have the right abstraction that allows you feed (remote) files into the editor. 

* Test that your root and its children show up and can be browsed 
* That that your provider isn't called like crazy
* Test that you get called to modify files (contents, times, etc)
* Test that your files feel like normal files but that certain operations (like reveal in finder) aren't available

data.title: Provide a way to prevent popups when typing.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (1.16.1)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6 (16G29)

There is currently no way to prevent popups from appearing as one types. I find this very frustrating. Sometimes I just want to type and be able to see the code in the document. But there are always a minimal of popups that are going to appear as you type. I would expect they would disappear as I type, but the don't, they follow the cursor. Clicking somewhere will dispel them or hitting ESC. But this breaks the pace of typing code. You should provide some kind of setting to prevent all popups for when users want/need to type without the distractions of popups. 

My current user settings are as follows:

```
{
    "editor.fontSize": 12,
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "editor.wordWrap": "on",
    "css.validate": false,
    "editor.fontFamily": "SF Mono, monospace",
    "editor.quickSuggestions": {
      "other": false,
      "comments": false,
      "strings": false,
      "editor.wordBasedSuggestions": false
    },
    "editor.quickSuggestionsDelay": 1000000,
    "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
    "editor.fontLigatures": true,
    "editor.wordBasedSuggestions": false,
    "editor.hover": false,
    "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0,
    "explorer.autoReveal": false,
    "emmet.syntaxProfiles": {
         "typescript": "html"
    },
    "emmet.includeLanguages": {"javascript":"javascriptreact"},
    "workbench.startupEditor": "newUntitledFile",
    "window.zoomLevel": 0
  }
```
Here's an image of what I'm talking about:

![vscode-popups](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/249218/30843691-b9d84792-a23f-11e7-86c1-caa0b9156028.png)

The popup "Component(props: any)..." is exactly over the area I need to type in. I do not need to see this popup about the call signature every time I try to add a member to the class.

data.title: Extension needs to be notified when it gets uninstalled
data.body:
When an extension is uninstalled, it needs to be notified of the uninstall event and do some cleanup before it is removed.

Here's the scenario. We have extension B which register some Java component in extension A. So when B is uninstalled, we would like to unregister B from A. Otherwise, A would attempt to load B's Java component in the next run, when B is already removed.

In our case, A is the Java Language Support from RedHat. B is the new Java debugger from Microsoft. Both ship Java artifacts which contain the real logic. So it's very important for the registration/unregistration to happen correctly.

data.title: Test: Improve automated issue management
data.body:
Testing #32238

Complexity 2

- [x] Any OS: @bpasero 
- [ ] Any OS: @ramya-rao-a 

In one of our satellite repos or a personal repo:
- Make sure the VSCode bot is installed (Repo Settings > Integrations & Services)
- Configure automatic assignment by checking in a file `.github/assignment.yml` with:
```
{
    perform: true,
    assignees: [ yourgithubid ]
}
```
  - Verify new issues are automatically assigned to the listed (comma separated) GitHub accounts.
  - Verify that if you assign a new issue to someone before submitting it, no automatic assignment is done.

In our main repo, configure multiple assignees (e.g., for workbench) in: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/.github/classifier.yml
- Verify only one of these assignees is assigned for that label and it is randomly picked.

Assigning @bpasero because he specifically asked for the random assignment and the classifier is really only operational on our main repo at this time.

data.title: Ensure rg is killed when vscode quits
data.body:
A subset of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34434

- Start a long-running search, e.g. on `/`
- Quit or reload the window
- The `rg` process should not continue running

Also
- Install the C# extension
- Open a large folder like `/`
- See busy `rg` process
- Quit or reload the window, and the `rg` process should terminate

data.title: Adding GDPR annotations
Test WSL
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/pull/156 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/pull/158:

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - @mjbvz 

For description of this feature pls see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/pull/156#issue-245375297.

Setup:
- install WSL on Windows 10.
- in Windows create a node.js test program and a launch config
- add a `"useWSL": "true"` attribute to the launch config
- launch the debug session

Verify for the "legacy" protocol that:
- the node.js version detection finds the correct node.js version on the linux side
- the debug session launches correctly and that you can step, set and hit breakpoints and view sources
